I don’t blame the Scarlets for being unable to get a team out, each side’s circumstances are unique, but I will massively credit Munster and Cardiff if they get sides out, as if all three have to forfeit the affect on the competition would be immense.

A once great competition that is now living off its legacy, a shambolic structure and not a priority for anyone except the fans who all still would love to see our teams win it.

Overall I think it’s interesting and some bits I like, but I remain very sceptical of regular cross hemisphere competition. Would rather clubs from different hemispheres played each other in two months of the year, one in north and one in south with tours or mini tournaments.

Other cons: 
- still a huge amount of travel involved 
- tv deal looks messy on first glance 
- playoffs potentially travel chaos (would prefer one city / two cities in one country for semis and finals like Nations league in football)

My take on #URC. 
Pros: 
- the name so long as they never use the long version and stick with URC
- not clashing with internationals 
- the NFL style 4 team groups with their own champion 

Major Con: 
- South African teams in to the European cup destroys the European cup

@markismith50 It incentivises both. So a particularly good \ generous owner is incentivised but so is an asset stripper. Premier Rugby urgently now needs to put some rules in place to protect against asset strippers rather than assuming all owners \ major shareholders have good intentions.

@MickHogan2 @Jbeardmore @neilfissler Anyway, interesting discussion, if all involved with PRL thought like yourself then I’d be more relaxed about the change, but I can’t help but see it as another protectionist measure for owners wealth not the good of the clubs they own.

@MickHogan2 @Jbeardmore @neilfissler They also don’t have an existing second tier which has seen a huge funding gap increase over the period due to protectionist measures and access to games vs the top tier cut off by the destruction of an existing cup.

@MickHogan2 @Jbeardmore @neilfissler Interesting comparison with MLS. They don’t have such an ongoing battle with the international game or constant change in laws of the game which I think have really hurt rugby in comparison over the same time.

@MickHogan2 @Jbeardmore @neilfissler And look at where the largest attendances are in both sports, how much have those strong local rivalries grown the support? I think a lot. I don’t think Wasps in Cov limit Coventry’s support at all, they could be rugby’s first non-London 2 team city.

@MickHogan2 @Jbeardmore @neilfissler My view is where we are historically, we are NFL in maybe 1960’s, Football league in maybe 1910’s in terms of how long we’ve been professional. There has been massive growth in rugby crowds since 1990, why can’t the next 30 years see the same?
@MickHogan2 @Jbeardmore @neilfissler And the premier league has how many two-team cities? Premier league is a massive success and yet has often had huge geographic holes.

@MickHogan2 @Jbeardmore @neilfissler If premier rugby has an ambitious vision or belief it can grow, they are not selling it. I love NFL but it does have issues, not least that teams can be uprooted to new cities, the potential to see more of that (given Wasps precedent) is one of my major issues with ringfencing.

@MickHogan2 @Jbeardmore @neilfissler The point I was making was building on JB’s point that it isn’t the absence of P&R that makes the NFL strong, it’s the comprehensive plan and strong organisation they have. They have not always been big or profitable. They have always had an ambitious vision.
@MickHogan2 @Jbeardmore @neilfissler Not true. They have had a variety of fixtures from the word go when they started with 16 teams.

@Jbeardmore @MickHogan2 @neilfissler The structure of the NFL also means you get both rivalries and a variety of fixtures over time. Do premier rugby have a plan to incorporate things like that too? Of course not.
